title: Foundation in Art and Animation Principles
description: Develop strong foundational art skills, especially drawing and sketching. Study the 12 basic principles of animation (squash and stretch, timing, etc.). This is the bedrock of all animation, whether 2D or 3D.
qualifications: A strong portfolio of drawings and basic animations
skills: Understanding of the 12 Principles of Animation

title: Master Software and Formal Education
description: Choose a path (2D or 3D) and learn the industry-standard software. For motion graphics, Adobe After Effects is key. For 3D, Autodesk Maya or Blender. A diploma or degree can provide a structured learning path and access to resources.

title: Junior Animator / Motion Graphics Artist
description: Join an animation studio, an advertising agency, or a TV production house. As a junior, you'll work on specific scenes or elements under the direction of a senior animator or art director. Focus on building a strong demo reel.
qualifications: A strong demo reel showcasing your skills

title: Mid-Level Animator / Senior Motion Designer
description: Take on more complex animation tasks, such as character acting shots or intricate motion graphics sequences. You'll work more independently and may start mentoring junior artists. You are a reliable artist who can deliver high-quality work consistently.

title: Animation Lead / Art Director / Freelance Specialist
description: Advance to a leadership role, supervising a team of animators and ensuring the quality and consistency of the animation in a project. Alternatively, become a highly sought-after freelance specialist known for a particular style or skill.
qualifications: Extensive professional experience and a stellar reel
